title: Report of the Haycraft Commission of Inquiry on Jaffa Disturbances
description:
The commission finds that the disturbances in Jaffa


 and its neighborhood were spontaneous and not planned. It notes that their fundamental cause is the Arab resentment against the Zionist project and Jewish immigration: "the general belief that the aims of the Zionists and Jewish immigration are a danger to the national and material interests of Arabs in Palestine is well nigh universal amongst the Arabs, and is not confined to any particular class."

title: The British Issue a Constitution for Palestine in the Form of an Order in Council; Non-Applicability to Transjordan
description:
Considered as a Constitution for Palestine, the Palestine Order in Council is signed by the King "on the adivce of his Privy Council." It defines the powers of the Executive (the High Commissioner) and the jurisdiction of the Judiciary and provides for the establishment of a 23-member Legislative Council


, 11 of whom are appointed high civil servants, The powers of the Legislative Council are subject to the provisions of the Mandate (i.e. including the establishment of a Jewish National Home in Palestine) and to the High Commissioner's assent. Article 86 of the Order stipulates, in effect, that it does not apply to Transjordan.On the same day, the King signs the "Palestine Legislative Council Election Order, 1922".

title: Start of the Arab Revolt against the Ottomans
description:
On the strength of the assurances he received from McMahon
, Sharif Hussein of Mecca


 declares Arab independence from Ottoman rule and starts the Arab revolt from Mecca


. His objective is to establish an Arab state stretching from Aden


 to Aleppo


 and including what will become Syria


, Lebanon


, Palestine, Transjordan


, and Iraq


. Mecca is liberated on 9 July and Ta'if


 on 22 September. Between 16 June and 26 January 1917, and with the assistance of British and French naval forces, the Arab army captures the Hijazi ports on the Red Sea

 (Jedda


, Yanbu'


 and Wejh


). However, it is unable to liberate Medina


 (the Ottoman garrison will surrender on 9 January 1919 only). The port of Aqaba


, the last port under Ottoman control will be captured by the Arab Army on 6 July 1917. This will provide a land connection between the Red Sea eastern coast, including the Gulf of Aqaba


, and British forces in the Sinai
 for a push northward.

title: Foundation of Tel Aviv
description:
Around 60 Zionists who reside in Jaffa


 and belong to a society called Ahuzat Bayit

 (House Estate), distribute among themselves some twelve acres of land they had purchased on the northern outskirts of the city with the purpose of building a Jewish quarter they name Ahuzat Bayit. The society was established in Summer 1906 and succeeded two years later in getting loans from the Jewish National Fund
. Yehiel Chlenov

, a JNF board member, explains the grant as the need to constitute Jewish modern urban neighborhoods in Palestine, in addition to agricultural settlements which were the main recipients of JNF support: "In the end, the healthiest solution for national existence posits that Jews should live in their own neighborhoods rather than be scattered among the other inhabitants, as presently exists." In 1910, the Ahuzat Bayit quarter is renamed Tel Aviv

 (City of Spring) in reference to the Hebrew-translated title of Theodor Herzl

’s 1902 novel Altneuland.

title: Formal Entry of General Allenby into Jerusalem
description:
Upon his entry on foot to the Old City of Jerusalem


 through Jaffa Gate

, General Allenby
 issues a proclamation in which he puts the city under martial law, promises that every inhabitant of Jerusalem may pursue “his lawful business without fear,” and pledges to protect the sacred sites of the three religions.

title: Foundation of the Zionist Paramilitary Group Hashomer
description:
The founders of the Bar Giora Group

 that was created in 1907 as an underground organization meet in Kfar Tavor

 colony (previously Mas-ha) in Tiberias


 subdistrict and decide to publicly establish, and merge into, a new organization they call Hashomer

 (the Guard). Its purpose is to guard Jewish settlements in Palestine and provide training. With the approval of the Jewish Colonization Association

, the new organization applies for a license to form a unit of 10 armed Jewish guards. Tiberias authorities grant the license; it includes the provision to increase the size of the unit if necessary. Israeli historians consider Hashomer as the nucleus of the  Haganah 

 and the Israeli army.

title: Provisional Law of Disposal of Immovable Property, 5 Jumada al-ula 1331
description: The remaining restrictions for an owner of miri land (private usufruct State land) to freely dispose of property are lifted. Two important exceptions remain, however: miri land, contrary to mulk (freehold land), cannot be dedicated as waqf, nor can it be bequeathed by will.

title: Palin Commission of Inquiry
description:
The British appoint a Commission of Inquiry on the aftermath of the disturbances related to the Nabi Musa festival. The commission (Palin Commission of Inquiry

), headed by Major-General Philip Palin

, submits its report on 1 July, but the report is not published due to Zionist pressure. Among the findings of the commission: an Arab sense of betrayal and disappointment at the nonfulfillment of British promises; inability to reconcile self-determination with the Balfour Declaration

; fear of Jewish domination justified by the apparent control exercised by the Zionists over the administration; and the fact that "The Zionist Commission

 and the official Zionists by their impatience, indiscretion and attempts to force the hands of the Administration, are largely responsible for the present crisis."

title: Palestinians Reject Arab Agency Scheme
4th Zionist Congress Is Held in London
description:
The 4th Zionist Congress resolves that a  Keren Kayemeth Leisrael (Jewish National Fund) 

 be founded as an organization charged to buy and develop land in Palestine.

title: 3rd Palestinian National Congress Meets in Haifa
description:
The 3rd Palestinian National Congress


 meets in Haifa. As the French occupy now Damascus and have put an end to Faisal's Arab Kingdom, the congress is led to give a predominantly Palestinian orientation to its political activities. It denounces the British for assuming legislative powers that should reside in an elected Parliament, and condemns the establishment of the Advisory Council
 whose members are to be appointed by the British. The congress elects a nine-member Arab Executive Committee


, headed by Musa Kazim al-Husseini


, to conduct business between congresses. Husseini will remain president of the Committee until his death in 1934, signaling the demise of the committee.

title: 8th Zionist Congress Is Held in the Hague
description:
The Zionist Congress decides to give precedence to practical colonization steps in Palestine (as opposed to obtaining an internationally recognized charter), to establish a Palestine branch of the organization, and to form a Palestine Land Development Company. The meeting is held in The Hague

 in order to give high visibility to the Zionist Congress during the Second International Peace Conference (June-October 1907), attended by representatives of world powers, that will lead to what is known as the 1907 Hague Convention

.

title: Hussein-McMahon Correspondence: Territorial Issues and Prelude to the Arab Revolt against the Ottomans
description:
Sir Henry McMahon

, British High Commissioner in Egypt


, exchanges letters with Sharif Hussein of Mecca


 to induce him to revolt against the Ottomans in exchange for British support for an independent Arab state. In a letter dated 25 October 1915, McMahon writes that "Great Britain

 is prepared to recognize and support the independence of the Arabs in all the regions within the limits demanded by the Sharif of Mecca


,"with the following exception: that "the two districts of Mersina


 and Alexandretta


 and portions of Syria


 lying to the west of the districts of Damascus


, Homs


, Hama


 and Aleppo


 cannot be said to be purely Arab, and should be excluded from the limits demanded". The letter explains that British assurances apply to "those regions lying within those frontiers wherein Great Britain is free to act without detriment to the interest of her ally, France

." In light of this letter, subsequent letters that are exchanged between Hussein and McMahon, and internal British documents (dated 1918 and 1919), Palestine (and Transjordan) is clearly included in the territory where Arabs will enjoy independence with British assistance. The British will deny, after the issuance of the Balfour Declaration

, that Palestine was ever intended for inclusion in the independent Arab territory.

title: French Occupy Damascus; Arab Syrian Kingdom Nominally Reduced to Transjordan
description:
France

, on the basis of its agreement with Great Britain

 (the Sykes-Picot Agreement

) and using the legal–diplomatic cover provided by the San Remo
 resolutions (25 April) that granted it mandate over Syria


, issues (14 July) an ultimatum to the Syrian Arab government to disband its troops and submit to French control. Though King Faisal
 tends to accept the ultimatum, his minister of defense Yusuf al-Azmeh


 refuses to give in. Poorly armed troops under Azmeh’s command confront French forces (advancing from the territory that will become Lebanon


) in Maysalun


 and are defeated on 24 July and Azmeh is killed in the battle. The following day, French troops occupy Damascus


, bringing an end to Faisal’s rule in Syria. On 31 August, French General Henri Gouraud

 proclaims the establishment of the State of Greater Lebanon


, which includes, in addition to the Mutasarrifiyya of Mount Lebanon


, Beirut


, the Biqa' Valley


 districts, and the cities of Tripoli


, Sidon
, and Tyre


 and their surroundings. Since Lebanon and Palestine have been carved out of the Arab Syrian Kingdom


 and handled separately, what remains nominally of the latter is reduced to Transjordan


 territory.

title: Elections Held for Fifth Ottoman Parliament; Six Representatives from Regions in Palestine
description:
The Fifth Ottoman Parliament

 is elected. Representatives from regions in Palestine are: Jerusalem


 (Sa'id al-Husseini


, Raghib al-Nashashibi


, Faidi al-Alami


), Nablus


 (Tafwiq Hammad


; Amin Abd al-Hadi


), Acre


 (Abd al-Fattah al-Sa'di


).

title: League of Nations Approves Exclusion of Transjordan Territory from the Jewish National Home
description:
On 14 September, the secretary-general of the League of Nations

 submits to the council a British memorandum presenting the steps that the British government proposes to take in order to give effect to article 25 of the Palestine Mandate. The memorandum contains a description of the boundary between Palestine and Transjordan


 and enumerates the clauses of the Mandate for Palestine that are not to be applicable to Transjordan: part of the preamble and nine articles, fully or partially. These clauses remove the territory of Transjordan from the provisions of the Mandate relating to the Jewish National Home. On 16 September, the council approves the British memorandum.

title: Palestine Police Ordinance Is Issued
description: British authorities establish the Palestine Police as a civilian police force, laying out its structure, powers, and duties and the guidelines for appointing, promoting, disciplining, and dismissing officers. The Ordinance also grants Mandate authorities the power to declare an area to be in “a disturbed or dangerous state,” prompting increased police presence (the cost of which would be borne by the inhabitants of the area), and to impose collective fines on such areas from which the government could compensate individuals who had suffered injury to body or property.

title: Scheduled Second Palestinian National Congress Cannot Meet
description:
The British Mandate authorities prevent the Second Palestinian National Congress


 from convening. (Participants had planned to protest the decision of the San Remo Conference

 incorporating the Balfour Declaration

 into the British Mandate over Palestine.) Some of the would-be participants--including Muhammad Ishaq Darwish


, representing the Arab Club


 (based in Jerusalem


); Fakhr al-Din al-Nashashibi


, from the Literary Club


 in Jerusalem; Rashid al-Haj Ibrahim


, delegate of the Muslim Association in Haifa


; and Jenin


 delegate Haidar Abd al-Hadi


--send a letter to the Syrian Congress, stating their position and asking the Syrian Congress leadership to form a Palestinian delegation (from Palestinian representatives present in Damascus


) that would travel directly to Europe to defend the Palestinian case.

title: Appointment of a British Chief Administrator for Palestine
description:
General Allenby
 appoints Arthur Wigram Money

 Chief Administrator for Palestine. At the beginning of his Palestine campaign, Allenby had appointed Brigadier Gilbert Clayton

 as the Chief Political Officer to the British forces, and later with the conquest of Jerusalem


, as the de facto administrator of the part of Palestine that had been conquered so far. Allenby divides also this territory into four districts: Jerusalem, Jaffa


, al-Majdal


, and Bir al-Sabi'


, each to be administered by a military governor.

title: Enactment of the Ottoman Associations Law
description:
The enactment of the Associations Law
 constitutes a response to political developments that had threatened Ottoman unity as envisioned by the Committee of Union and Progress

 (CUP) and the latter’s dominance in the empire. After the CUP restored the 1876 constitution in July 1908, many ethnic-based cultural and political clubs (Albanian, Armenian, Bulgarian Greek, Jewish, Serbian, and Arab) were quickly formed in the name of freedom of association. A counterrevolution of April 1909 succeeded in expelling the CUP from Istanbul

 for 10 days. Under the new law, the formation of an association is not conditioned on prior authorization, but the new association is required to notify the authorities and may not “aim to undermine public order or territorial integrity, to change the current form of government, or to politically detach the various nationalities of the Empire from the State.” “Political associations borrowing their object and title from a race or nationality” are prohibited.

title: Mewat Land Ordinance
description: The Mewat Land Ordinance is issued, making it illegal for residents to acquire me​wat land (vacant or grazing land not owned by anyone) for the purpose of reviving it. This ordinance (like the Mahlul Land Ordinance passed four months earlier) is taken by the British Mandate to extend its grip on Palestinian land by repealing crucial Ottoman provisions that made it possible to acquire unused land. The new ordinance, which threatens offenders with prosecution, sets off an immediate uproar among the Arab leadership.

title: 6th Palestinian National Congress Is Held in Jaffa
description:
The Palestinian National Congress


 states its rejection of the Advisory Council
 (which the British High Commissioner had attempted to revive in view of his failure to form a Legislative Council) and decides to send a third Palestinian delegation to London

.

title: 6th Palestinian National Congress Is Held in Jaffa
description:
The Palestinian National Congress


 states its rejection of the Advisory Council
 (which the British High Commissioner had attempted to revive in view of his failure to form a Legislative Council) and decides to send a third Palestinian delegation to London

.

The Palestinian National Congress


 states its rejection of the Advisory Council
 (which the British High Commissioner had attempted to revive in view of his failure to form a Legislative Council) and decides to send a third Palestinian delegation to London

.

title: 6th Palestinian National Congress Is Held in Jaffa
description:
The Palestinian National Congress


 states its rejection of the Advisory Council
 (which the British High Commissioner had attempted to revive in view of his failure to form a Legislative Council) and decides to send a third Palestinian delegation to London

title: Zionist-Palestinian Violence Breaks out in Jaffa
description:
A fight involving the use of firearms breaks out in Jaffa


 between dozens of young Jews and Arabs and leaves 15 persons injured. The local police intervene in favor of the Arabs and walk into two hotels where Jews, mostly new immigrants from Prussia

, reside. Due to Jewish leaders' and European consuls' pressure on the government in Istanbul

, Jaffa's qa’im maqam is removed from his post. This Jewish-Arab urban violence is the first of its kind to occur in Palestine. Until then, disputes had erupted in rural areas over land ownership and tenancy or right of passage.

title: Elections Held for Third Ottoman Parliament; Five Representatives from Regions in Palestine
description:
The Third Ottoman Parliament

 convenes following elections in all provinces of the Empire, as an outcome of the Young Turk Revolution

 and the restoration of the 1876 constitution. Though the ratio of Arabs to Turks in the Empire is roughly 3 to 2, the Committee of Union and Progress had demarcated the electoral constituencies in such a way that, out of a total of 245 elected representatives, the Parliament includes 150 Turks and 60 Arabs. It includes five deputies representing the regions that will become Palestine: Sanjaq of Jerusalem


 (Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


, Sa'id al-Husseini


, Hafiz al-Sa'id


), Sanjaq of Nablus


 (Ahmad al-Khammash


), and Sanjaq of Acre


 (As'ad al-Shuqairi


). The Parliament is dissolved in January 1912.

title: The Arab Congress Meets in Paris
description: The Arab Congress (known also as the First Arab Congress, the Arab National Congress, or the Arab-Syrian Congress) meets in Paris with the participation of young Arab nationalists (from Greater Syria, Palestine, Istanbul, and Egypt). Participants, many of whom belong to the Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization (Cairo), the Young Arab Society (Paris), the Literary Club (Istanbul), and a group called the Beirut Committee for Reform, adopt a number of resolutions that call the Ottoman Empire to take, inter alia, the following steps: to make urgent and radical reforms; to ensure Ottoman Arabs' exercise of their political rights by making effective their participation in the central administration of the empire; to establish in each of the Syrian and Arab provinces a decentralizing system appropriate to its needs and abilities; and to have the Arabic language recognized in the Ottoman Parliament and considered as an official language in the Syrian and Arab provinces.

title: Elections Held for Fourth Ottoman Parliament; Five Representatives from Regions in Palestine
description:
Several regions in Palestine elect delegates to the Fourth Ottoman Parliament

: Jerusalem


 (Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


, Othman al-Nashashibi


, Ahmed Arif al-Husseini


); Nablus


 (Haydar Tuqan


); Acre


 (As'ad al-Shuqairi


). al-Khalidi is elected deputy president of the Parliament. The latter is dissolved on 5 August following a government crisis in Istanbul

.

title: Elections Held for Fourth Ottoman Parliament; Five Representatives from Regions in Palestine
description:
Several regions in Palestine elect delegates to the Fourth Ottoman Parliament

: Jerusalem


 (Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


, Othman al-Nashashibi


, Ahmed Arif al-Husseini


); Nablus


 (Haydar Tuqan


); Acre


 (As'ad al-Shuqairi


). al-Khalidi is elected deputy president of the Parliament. The latter is dissolved on 5 August following a government crisis in Istanbul

.

title: Opening of the Paris Peace Conference
description: The victorious allied powers (principally France, Great Britain, the US and Italy) open the conference in Paris to set the peace terms for the defeated powers, including the fate of territories that were part, or under the control, of the later, and to find an institutional mechanism for a new international order.

title: Proclamations No. 75 and No. 76 on Immovable Property
description:
“All dispositions [...] of immovable property” are prohibited in areas conquered by the British forces, in order to maintain the status quo

 and prevent impoverished landowners from selling their lands, from which many peasants would be driven away as a result. Zionist institutions voice their support. (They had been worried that an opening of the Land Registries would lead to unprecedented speculation and large-scale dedication of lands into Waqf.)

title: 2nd Wave of Jewish Immigration to Palestine
description:
The second wave of Jewish immigration to Palestine (which lasts until 1914) consists of around 40,000 immigrants many of whom have a strong ideological commitment to Zionism

 and call for the "conquest of the land" and the "conquest of labor." This anti-Arab attitude, which expresses itself in the expulsion of Palestinian fellahin from the settlements in which they work, will aggravate the disputes in Palestine between Jewish colonies and neighbouring Arab rural communities.

title: Completion of the Hijaz Railway
description:
A new railway connects Damascus


 to Medina


; its headquarters are located in Haifa


.

title: Completion of the Hijaz Railway
description:
A new railway connects Damascus


 to Medina


; its headquarters are located in Haifa


.

title: Completion of the Hijaz Railway
description:
A new railway connects Damascus


 to Medina


; its headquarters are located in Haifa


.

title: Completion of the Hijaz Railway
description:
A new railway connects Damascus


 to Medina


; its headquarters are located in Haifa


.

title: Emerging Palestinian Identity and Arab Nationalism
description: Several developments demonstrate and contribute to the emergence of Palestinian identity within and in parallel with Arab nationalism: publication of Najib Azoury’s book on the awakening of the Arab nation (1905); the newspapers al-Quds (Jerusalem, 1908), al-Karmel (Haifa, 1908), and Filastin (Jaffa, 1911); participation of Palestinians in Arab nationalist societies, both secret and public, that are created between 1908 and 1913 as a response to the "Turkification" policy following the 1908 Young Turk revolution; clashes of Palestinian peasants with Zionist settlers in protest against their land acquisition. Other factors had contributed earlier to Palestinian local identity, including Ottoman response to the European political and religious-cultural penetration of Palestine by the establishment of Jerusalem as an "independent" sanjaq reporting directly to Istanbul (1872) and memoranda addressed by Jerusalem notables to Istanbul protesting Jewish immigration.

title: Establishment of the Rawdat al-Ma'arif al-Wataniyya al-'Uthmaniyya al-Islamiyya in Jerusalem
description:
The National Ottoman Islamic School


, the first private Muslim school to offer a modern curriculum reflecting patriotic, Ottoman, and Islamic cultural trends, is founded in Jerusalem


. During the British Mandate period, the school will be known as the "Kulliyat Rawdat al-Ma'arif al-Wataniyya".

title: Establishment of the Rawdat al-Ma'arif al-Wataniyya al-'Uthmaniyya al-Islamiyya in Jerusalem

, the first private Muslim school to offer a modern curriculum reflecting patriotic, Ottoman, and Islamic cultural trends, is founded in Jerusalem


. During the British Mandate period, the school will be known as the "Kulliyat Rawdat al-Ma'arif al-Wataniyya".

. During the British Mandate period, the school will be known as the "Kulliyat Rawdat al-Ma'arif al-Wataniyya".

title: Six Jewish Colonies Are Established in Palestine between 1908 and 1910
description:
Five Jewish colonies are established in the Sanjaq of Acre


: Atlit

, Deganiya

, Kinneret

, Migdal

, and Mitspa

. One colony, Hulda

, is established in the Sanjaq of Jerusalem


.

title: Establishment of the Qahtani Society in Istanbul
description:
In the fall of 1909 in Istanbul

, members of the Literary Club


 and Arab officers in the Ottoman army form the Qahtani Society


, a secret grouping to avoid repression by the Ottoman authorities. The society, which counts among its founders Ali al-Nashashibi


 of Jerusalem


 (a doctor in the Ottoman army), aims to transform the Ottoman state into a federation under the Ottoman sultan that includes a Turkish state and an Arab state, each with its own parliament and government, similar to the Austro-Hungarian Empire

. The founders set up five branches in the Arab states in addition to Istanbul, taking care to choose members who could be absolutely trusted. However, during the second year, the society’s leaders fear the betrayal of one of its members and stop meeting. The association is thus dissolved de facto.

title: Establishment of al-Madrasa al-Dusturiyya, Jerusalem
description:
Khalil al-Sakakini


 establishes al-Madrasa al-dusturiyya
 (Constitutional School) in Jerusalem


; it is the first private secular school in Palestine.

title: Establishment of al-Madrasa al-Dusturiyya, Jerusalem
description:
Khalil al-Sakakini


 establishes al-Madrasa al-dusturiyya
 (Constitutional School) in Jerusalem


; it is the first private secular school in Palestine.

title: Establishment of al-Madrasa al-Dusturiyya, Jerusalem
description:
Khalil al-Sakakini


 establishes al-Madrasa al-dusturiyya
 (Constitutional School) in Jerusalem


; it is the first private secular school in Palestine.

title: Establishment of al-Madrasa al-Dusturiyya, Jerusalem
description:
Khalil al-Sakakini


 establishes al-Madrasa al-dusturiyya
 (Constitutional School) in Jerusalem


; it is the first private secular school in Palestine.

title: Formation of the Young Arab Society in Paris
description:
Awni Abd al-Hadi


, Rafiq al-Tamimi


, and Rushdi al-Shawa


, along with other Arab students in Paris

, found the secret Young Arab Society


 to work for the independence of the Arab provinces. In 1913, with the graduation of some of its members, the society's center moves to Beirut


, and the following year to Damascus


. The society has only 60 members until the end of World War I

, because a series of tough probation steps is followed for admission of a new member before being sworn in, so much so that the organization's existence is kept secret until after the Ottoman forces withdraw from the Arab provinces in 1918. Members will play a prominent role in the preparations for the First Arab Congress


 in Paris in June 1913 and in the run-up to the 1916 Great Arab Revolt


, and they will emerge as Prince Faisal


’s aides with the establishment of Arab rule in Damascus in the fall of 1918.

title: Railway Lines in Palestine
description:
Railway lines connecting Haifa


 to Acre


 and Afula


 to Nablus


 are completed, further expanding local infrastructure and control.

title: Establishment in New York of the Palestine Anti-Zionism Society (Later Renamed Palestine National League)
description:
Fuad Shatara


, Habib Katibah


, and other Arab Americans hailing from Greater Syria


 (i.e. what will become Palestine, Syria


, and Lebanon


) establish the Palestine Anti-Zionism Society


 in New York

. In 1919, the society publishes a book in Arabic entitled Reconstruction of Palestine, devoted mainly to Palestine's economic and social potentials and to the dangers represented by the Zionist project. Arab American contributors include John Salah


, Philip Hitti


, Victoria Tannous


, Fuad Shatara, and Habib Katibah. In 1921, the society renames itself the Palestine National League (known also as the Palestine Renaissance Society, a translation from its appellation in Arabic) and publishes a book edited by Habib Katibah titled The Case Against Zionism. Its publication in English expresses the league's emerging intent to influence the American public scene.

title: 3rd Wave of Jewish Immigration to Palestine
description: More than 35,000 Zionists immigrate to Palestine (3rd wave of immigration). (Between 1914 and 1918, one third of the Jewish population in Palestine emigrates.)

title: 4th Wave of Jewish Immigration to Palestine
description: More than 67,000 Zionists immigrate to Palestine.

title: Establishment of the Zionist Revisionist Movement
description:
The Zionist  ">Revisionist Movement 

 is founded in Palestine by Ze'ev (Vladimir) Jabotinsky

 (along with the youth movement Betar

), with the stated objective of establishing a Jewish state on both banks of the Jordan River


.

title: The Ottomans Sign the Treaty of Sèvres; The Turkish National Assembly in Ankara Rejects It
description:
Ottoman representatives coming from occupied Istanbul

 sign the Treaty of Sèvres
 as dictated by the Allied Powers

. The pact consecrates the shrinking of the Ottoman territory, leaving only Istanbul and Western Anatolia

 to an Ottoman government that is to remain under the tight control of the Allied Powers. However, nine days after the signing, the Turkish National Assembly

, which was established in Ankara

 under the aegis of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk

 on 23 April 1920, rejects the treaty altogether.

title: Third Stage of British Palestine Campaign: Completion of the Conquest of Palestine
description:
British forces conquer the part of Palestine that had remained under Ottoman control since December 1917. On 20 September, they capture Tulkarm


, Jenin


, Afula


, and Baysan


. The following day, they seize Nazareth


 and Nablus


. Haifa


 and Acre


 are conquered on 23 September, and Tiberias


 and Samakh


 two days later. By 26 September, no organized Ottoman troops remain in what will become the Palestine territory of the Mandate.

title: World War I, the Ottomans Enter the War
description:
World War I

 breaks out, and it quickly leads to a series of events that affect the future of the Ottoman Empire

. In September, the Ottomans decide to abolish capitulations that once afforded European powers special status within the empire. In November, they officially enter the war on the German side. In December, the British annex Cyprus

 and declare Egypt


 a protectorate. In January 1915, the Ottomans occupy the Sinai peninsula. By February the Gallipoli campaign

 begins to put Ottoman lands within the apex of the imperial battlefield of the war.

description:

. In September, the Ottomans decide to abolish capitulations that once afforded European powers special status within the empire. In November, they officially enter the war on the German side. In December, the British annex Cyprus

title: Collective Responsibility for Crime Ordinance Comes into Force
description: The Collective Responsibility for Crime Ordinance allows Mandate authorities to hold entire villages or tribes responsible for crimes committed by “persons unknown” and thus to impose collective fines on these communities or force them to pay for auxiliary police posts.

title: Palestine Civil Government and Appointment of Herbert Samuel as High Commisioner
description:
A “civil government” is established, replacing the British military administration of Palestine (Occupied Enemy Territory Administration

 South). The function of High Commissioner is created and Herbert Samuel

 is appointed to the post. Samuel, an ardent Zionist, had submitted to the British cabinet in early 1915, a memorandum entitled "The Future of Palestine" in which he explained that the course of events opened the possibility of changing the status of Palestine and making some advance towards "the restoration of the Jews" in Palestine. Adding that "the time is not ripe for the establishment there of an independent, autonomous Jewish State", he advocated "the annexation of the country to the British Empire," until that time and thanks to Jewish immigration, purchase of land and establishment of institutions, Jewish majority and self-government are attained.

title: Palestine Gendarmerie Is Established
description: After the disturbances of May 1921, the British administration moves to establish a gendarmerie that can act as a mobile strike-force to patrol rural areas and suppress protests and riots in urban areas. In July 1921, the local section of the gendarmerie is established, with the desired composition being evenly divided between Arab Muslims, Jews, and local minority groups (such as Circassians and Druze). Meanwhile, the British sets about raising a British component of the gendarmerie, whose men are largely recruited from the Royal Irish Constabulary and its auxiliary units, popularly known as Black and Tans, whose formation is formally announced with the British Gendarmerie Ordinance of 24 April 1922.

title: Provisional Law Concerning the Right of Certain Corporate Bodies to Own Immovable Property, 22 Rabi' al-awwal 1331
description: The right to own property is extended to juridical persons, corporate bodies such as companies, societies, and charitable institutions. (Previously only natural persons, i.e. individuals, had that right.)

title: Provisional Law Concerning the Right of Certain Corporate Bodies to Own Immovable Property, 22 Rabi' al-awwal 1331
description: The right to own property is extended to juridical persons, corporate bodies such as companies, societies, and charitable institutions. (Previously only natural persons, i.e. individuals, had that right.)

title: Provisional Law Concerning the Right of Certain Corporate Bodies to Own Immovable Property, 22 Rabi' al-awwal 1331
description: The right to own property is extended to juridical persons, corporate bodies such as companies, societies, and charitable institutions. (Previously only natural persons, i.e. individuals, had that right.)

title: Provisional Law Concerning the Right of Certain Corporate Bodies to Own Immovable Property, 22 Rabi' al-awwal 1331
description: The right to own property is extended to juridical persons, corporate bodies such as companies, societies, and charitable institutions. (Previously only natural persons, i.e. individuals, had that right.)

title: May Day Clashes in Jaffa
description:
The clashes occur first among Jews in Tel Aviv

 celebrating the "First of May": a group of communists calling for "international solidarity of the Jewish and Arab proletariat" and heading from the outskirts of Jaffa


 toward Tel Aviv collide with the main demonstration by the Zionist Labour movement. Tension mounts between Palestinian and Jewish demonstrators, and then confrontation spreads rapidly. Three days of clashes result in the death of 43 Jews and 14 Palestinians. On 5 and 6 May, the explosive situation reaches Petah Tikva

, al-Yahudiyya


 (renamed al-Abbasiyya


 in 1932), and Hadera

, causing the death of 4 Jews and 54 Palestinians (for the latter, mainly due to the intervention of the British military). On 7 May, High Commissioner Herbert Samuel

 appoints Palestine Chief Justice Thomas Haycraft

 to head a commission of inquiry into the disturbances.

title: Ottoman-Egyptian Separating Line Agreement
description:
Egyptian and Ottoman representatives sign in Rafah


 ”Administrative Separating Line" between the Mutasarrifiyya of Jerusalem


 and the Province of Hijaz


 on one side and, on the other side, the Sinai Peninsula


 (being considered part of Egypt


). The line, which runs from Rafah on the Mediterranean Sea

 to Taba


 on the Red Sea

, is not formally considered as an international frontier, since Egypt, though under British control, is nominally part of the Ottoman Empire

. The agreement puts an end to a risk of military confrontation that occurred in February when Ottoman troops were deployed in Taba in response to British posting of Egyptian border police at Umm al-Rashrash


. In 1919, the British controlling both Palestine and Egypt will adopt the line demarcated in 1906 as the frontier between the two territories.

title: Transfer of Land Ordinance
description: Together with reopening the Land Registry Offices that were closed in November 1918, the British issue the ordinance that authorizes dispositions of land but under strict conditions, in order to curb land speculation and protect landowners and tenants against landlessness. (These provisions later prove ineffective in the face of multiple circumvention schemes developed by Zionist institutions.)

title: Mahlul Land Ordinance
description: The British authorities pass an ordinance to control acquisition of mahlul land. Under the Ottomans, mahlul land (consisting in miri which has not been cultivated for more than three years or whose owner has passed away without heirs) could easily be granted to any interested party; the new ordinance renders such possession illegal and subject to heavy penalties and allows only leasing to occupants. This complete turnaround is part of the overall British objective, entangled in Zionist interests, to bring as much land as possible under exclusive State control.

title: 12th Zionist Congress Is Held in Carlsbad (Karlovy Vary)
description:
The Zionist Congress
(which had last met in 1913) welcomes the Balfour Declaration

 and the decision of the Allies
 to grant Great Britain

 the Mandate over Palestine. Chaim Weizmann

 is elected president of the  World Zionist Organization 

.

title: 5th Palestinian National Congress Meets in Nablus
description:
The 5th Palestinian National Congress


  reviews the results of the visit to London by the Palestinian delegation whose formation was decided by the 4th Congress in June 1921. It affirms its struggle toward independence and denounces the proposed Constitution for Palestine which provides, in particular, for the establishment of a Legislative Council. It refuses participation in the elections for the Council, citing the following reasons: its purpose is to implement the Jewish National Home in Palestine; Palestinian representatives would always be a minority in the Council (compared to the majority constituted by the appointed civil servants and the Jewish representatives); and the decisions of the Council would always require the approval of the High Commissioner.

title: Regulation Concerning the Supreme Moslem Sharia Council
description:
The British High Commissioner, Herbert Samuel

, issues an Order containing the regulation relative to the establishment of a Supreme Moslem Sharia Council


, its formation, its responsibilities, and the rules governing its work. Responsibilities include: (1) control of the Moslem Religious Courts and nomination of judges, to be approved by the Government; (2) control and administration of waqf and the approval of the annual waqf budget; and (3) appointment of muftis. The regulation is put forward by a committee of muftis, ulama, and Muslim notables that was constituted in November 1920. (A first text was approved and published by the High Commissioner in the Palestine Gazette on 15 May 1921 and then amended in December.) Muhammad Amin al-Husseini


, mufti of Jerusalem


, is elected President of the Council on 9 January 1922.

title: House of Lords and House of Commons Conflicting Views on Palestine
description: The House of Lords in London adopts a motion (60 in favor, 29 against) on 20 June, considering that "the Mandate for Palestine in its present form is inacceptable to this House, because it directly violates the pledges made by His Majesty’s Government to the people of Palestine... and is, as at present framed, opposed to the sentiments and wishes of the great majority of the people of Palestine." On 4 July, the House of Commons concludes a debate dealing with Palestine and other British colonies in Asia and Africa by approving (by 292 votes; 35 against) the government's colonial budget, thus condoning implicitly the British Mandate for Palestine, and the Balfour Declaration as part of the Mandate.

title: Appointment of the King-Crane Commission
description:
On the suggestion of US
 President Woodrow Wilson

, the 1919 Paris Peace Conference

 decides in principle to send an international commission of inquiry to ascertain the aspirations of Middle East / الشرق الأوسط
 peoples after the defeat of the Ottoman Empire

. On 27 March, Wilson appoints Henry Churchill King

 and Charles R. Crane

  as American representatives in the commission. However, France

 and then Great Britain

 decline to appoint their respective reprensentatives. The commission, reduced to its "American Section", will be known as the King-Crane Commission

. It tours the region from 10 June to 21 July 1919.

title: Jemal Pasha Orders the Public Hanging of Arab Nationalists from the Levant
description:
Ahmad Jemal Pasha
, the Ottoman military governor of the Levant
, accuses intellectuals and journalists from the Levant (known later as Lebanon


, Syria


, Palestine, and Transjordan


) of working to get rid of Ottoman rule. After a mock trial of detainees, he orders the execution by hanging of more than 30 of them (in addition to dozens tried in absentia). Executions are carried out in two phases: the first in Beirut


 on 21 August 1915; the second in Beirut and Damascus


 on 6 May 1916. Those who come from the area that will become Mandate Palestine

 are Salim Ahmad Abd al-Hadi
 (Arraba


), Mohammed al-Shanti al-Yafi


 (Jaffa


), and Ali Omar al-Nashashibi
 (Jerusalem


). Hafiz al-Sa'id


 (Jaffa) and Sa'id al-Karmi


 (Tulkarm


) who are also sentenced to death, have their sentence commuted to life imprisonment because of their age. In late 1916, Ahmed Aref al-Husseini


, mufti of Gaza


, and his son Mustafa
 will be executed in Jerusalem.

title: Limited British Advances; Stabilization of the Military Front
description:
On 21 December, British forces battle the Ottomans across al-Auja River


 (five kilometers north of Jaffa


) and consolidate their position seven kilometers further to the north. Ottoman forces attempt a counterattack from the north of Jerusalem


. A battle at Tel al-Ful


 (Beit Hanina


) on 26–27 December is won by the British, who in the days that follow extend their control to the Ni'lin


–Baytin


 line. The same occurs to the east with the capture of Jericho


 (19–21 February 2018). Further British advances take place (8–12 March) on a west–east line extending from north of al-Auja River to Deir Ballout


, Turmusayya


, Wadi al-Auja


, and the Jordan River


. An attempt to advance further north toward Tulkarm


 and Nablus


 (9–21 April) gives the British limited gains with the capture of Brukin


 and Rafat


. The British–Ottoman front then stabilizes until September 1918.

title: British Failed Attempts to Conquer Transjordan
description:
British forces cross Damiya Bridge


 from Palestine to Transjordan


 in an attempt to conquer al-Salt


 and Amman


 and disable the Hijaz Railway

, an important logistic line for the Ottomans, on two occasions: 21 March–2 April and 30 April–4 May. They fail on both occasions and withdraw back to Palestine territory. However, Arab troops that helped the British invade Palestine assist British forces through harassing the Ottomans and threatening their supply lines (e.g., trying to capture Ma'an


 and its railway station.

title: British Conquest of Transjordan Is Achieved
description:
The fall of Nablus


 allows British forces to control the road to Damiya Bridge


 and to seize the bridge on 22 September and al-Salt


 the following day. Amman


 is easily conquered on 25 September, because at this point and in view of the British progress toward Baysan


 and Tiberias


, Ottoman forces see no option other than to retreat northward.

title: 6th Zionist Congress Is Held in Basel
description:
The 6th Zionist Congress discusses an offer made by British politician and leading imperialist Joseph Chamberlain

 to establish an autonomous Jewish settlement in East Africa

 (Uganda

). Justified as a temporary solution and not as an alternative to Palestine, the scheme gives rise to considerable opposition and walk-outs. However, a resolution is adopted to send an "investigatory commission" to examine the territory proposed. A Palestine Commission paralleling the East Africa Investigatory Commission is formed.

title: Signing of a Franco-British Convention on Mandate Boundaries
description: French and British representatives sign in Paris a convention to regulate boundary-related issues resulting from the distribution of mandates to their respective countries over territories that were part of the Ottoman Empire. The convention determines the boundaries between Syria (including Lebanon) on one hand, and Palestine (including Transjordan, to allay British fears concerning French intentions toward this remaining territory of the Arab Syrian Kingdom) and Iraq on the other hand. The convention institutes a commission that will trace on the spot the boundary lines, and resolves some cross-border issues (such as water, irrigation, railway, and passage of employees). It deals also with existing schools directed by nationals of the other country: it allows the continuation of their work but excludes the implication that  either country can open new schools in the Mandate area of the other.

title: Young Turk Revolution
description:
Army officers loyal to the Committee of Union and Progress

 take control of Istanbul

 and force Sultan Abd al-Hamid II


 to restore the 1876 constitution and call for parliamentary elections. The revolution is first welcomed by the Arabs. Then the CUP, in its efforts toward a centralized government, will progressively imprint the empire with a Turkish character rather than an encompassing Ottoman one and thus alienate the Arabs and other components of the Sultanate. Predominantly-Arab parties and Arab secret societies will be formed and will contribute to strengthening Arab political identity within the Ottoman Empire or against it before and throughout World War I.

title: A Zionist–Arab Incident in Zarnuqa
description:
Guards from Rehovot

 affiliated with the Zionist paramilitary group Hashomer

 clash with Arab laborers from Zarnuqa


 over an accusation of theft of grapes from a Jewish-cultivated vineyard. The incident escalates into a larger skirmish between the settlers and the Arab rural population, resulting in casualties on both sides. The incident, which receives attention in newspapers and is the subject of petitions addressed to the Ottoman authorities, is seen as more than a local dispute and will have significant political repercussions; it will mark a turning point in Jewish-Arab relations in Ottoman Palestine

.

title: The Sykes-Picot Agreement Defines the British and French Spheres of Influence over the Ottoman Arab Provinces
description:
On 23 November, one month after McMahon
's letter to Sharif Hussein of Mecca


 supporting an independent Arab state after the fall of the Ottoman Empire

, British and French representatives meet to negotiate their respective countries' future spheres of influence over the Ottoman Arab provinces (and Turkish Cilicia

). On 3 February 1916, after a series of meetings, British Mark Sykes

 and French François Georges Picot

 reach a deal they present to Russian foreign minister Sergueï Sazonov

. The latter gives his government's consent 26 April, in return for agreeing to Russia

's demand to take over Constantinople

 and other portions of the Ottoman Empire. The secret Sykes-Picot
 text (including map) is finalized on 8-9 May and ratified on 16 May. It provides, in particular, for the delimitation of a "brown area" on the map, covering part of what will become Mandate Palestine

 and where "shall be established an international administration, the form of which is to be decided upon after consultation with Russia, and subsequently in consultation with the other allies, and the representatives of the sheriff of Mecca


."

title: General Allenby Issues Guidelines for the Military Occupation of the Levant
description:
With the Ottoman Empire

’s loss of its Arab provinces, the British and French attempt to allocate them, temporarily, between themselves, taking into account the terms of the Sykes-Picot Agreement

 and the military situation on the ground. Consequently, General Allenby
 issues (23 October) guidelines related to what is called Occupied Enemy Territory Administration

 (OETA). OETA South, which covers the sanjaqs of Jerusalem
, Nablus
, and Acre
, is put under British military rule. It corresponds roughly to the international zone of the Sykes-Picot agreement and also to what will become the territory of the British Mandate west of the Jordan
. OETA North (renamed OETA West in December) which includes the Mutasarrifiyya of Mount Lebanon


 and the Vilayet of Beirut
 (minus the sanjaqs of Nablus and Acre) is allocated to the French, in line with Sykes-Picot agreement, but excludes the districts of Baalbek


, Hasbayya


, and Rashayya


 which are to form part of OETA East. OETA East, under British–Arab control, consists roughly of Syria


 and Transjordan


, in addition to the three mentioned districts, but its eastern boundary is not precisely determined.

title: The League of Nations Confirms Britain’s Mandate over Palestine
description:
The Council of the League of Nations

 confirms Britain
’s mandate over Palestine. In contrast to France

’s mandate over Syria


, the text on Palestine does not request from the mandatory power the enactment, within three years, of an "organic law" in agreement with "the native authorities", but gives the British "full powers of legislation and of administration" . It reiterates, in particular, Britain’s commitment to the Zionist project as phrased in the Balfour Declaration

 (article 2). It also decides that an “appropriate Jewish agency shall be recognized as a public body for the purpose of advising and cooperating” with the Mandatory Power in matters related to the establishment of the Jewish National Home and specifies that the Zionist Organization

 will be considered as such agency and requests it to secure the cooperation of all Jews who are willing to assist in the establishment of the Jewish National Home (article 4). The document authorizes the Mandatory power, subject to the League’s consent, to withhold the application of some of its provisions, in the territory east of the Jordan River


 (article 25). An accompanying resolution of the council stipulates that the mandates for Palestine and Syria will enter into force, automatically and at the same time, as soon as France and Italy

 sign an agreement resolving particular points related to France’s mandate over Syria.

title: Treaty of Lausanne Is Signed with Ataturk's Turkey
description:
Under the Treaty of Lausanne

, the Republic of Turkey

, led by Mustafa Kemal Atatürk

, is officially recognized as the successor state to the Ottoman Empire

. The treaty replaces the 1920 Treaty of Sèvres
 which had been rejected by the Turkish National Assembly

 meeting in Ankara

 under the auspices of Atatürk. The Treaty of Lausanne defines the borders of Turkey, recognizing its sovereignty over Anatolia

 and Eastern Thrace

. In Article 16, Turkey renounces "all rights and title whatsoever over or respecting the territories situated outside the frontiers laid down in the present Treaty." This naturally concerns the bordering territories of Iraq


 0and Syria


 and consequently Palestine and Transjordan


.

title: San Remo Conference: Distribution of Mandates
description:
The San Remo Conference

, attended by representatives of the Allied Powers

 (Great Britain

, France

, Italy

, and Japan

), adopts resolutions that incorporate the Sykes-Picot Agreement

 to a significant extent. The conference grants France "mandate" over Syria


 (covering what will become Syria and Lebanon


), and Britain is granted “mandate” over Mesopotamia

 and Palestine (covering what will become Iraq


, Palestine and Transjordan


). In relation to Article 22 of the League of Nations Covenant

 (which says in paragraph 4 that ex-Ottoman communities "can be provisionally recognized as independent States" and that their "wishes must be a principal consideration in the selection of the Mandatory"), the conference distinguishes between Syria and Mesopotamia on one side, with Palestine on the other side. On Syria and Mesopotamia, the conference recalls the independence provision of Article 22 but does not refer to the communities’ "wishes." On Palestine, the conference recalls Article 22 but makes no mention of the community’s wishes or to independence. It reserves instead a specific provision that the Mandatory power will be responsible for implementing the Balfour Declaration

.

title: British Formal and Conditional Assurance to Transjordan's Abdullah
description:
Pressed over many months by Emir Abdullah


 for a British–Transjordanian treaty recognizing the full independence of Transjordan


, the British finally issue a short text stipulating that it “would” recognize the existence of an independent government in Transjordan under Emir Abdullah’s rule, provided it was constitutional and permitted Britain
 to fulfil its “international obligations” (i.e. toward the League of Nations

). The declaration indicates that such British recognition would have to be achieved by means of an agreement to be concluded between the two governments. The declaration is not published in London

 but is pronounced in Amman


 on 25 April by Herbert Samuel

, who allegedly acts not as head of the Palestine administration but as representative of the Mandatory power. On 25 May, Emir Abdullah considers the declaration as British recognition of the independence of Transjordan.

title: The Issue of the Administration of Transjordan
description:
The end of Faisal
’s rule raises the issue of the future of Transjordan


. The French reassure the British that they will not expand their influence over this territory (though it was part of the Arab Kingdom
 under Faisal) and that they will respect the Sykes-Picot
 line. On 23 December, a Frenco-British Convention confirms the Syria


–Transjordan border. The British themselves do not wish to expand the administration of Palestine across Transjordan, though High Commissioner Herbert Samuel

 advocates for the expansion, in an attempt to include the territory within the Jewish National Home. The British send political officers to encourage localized self-government in the three districts (Irbid


, al-Salt


, and al-Karak


) that constitute Transjordanian territory. But within several months, it appears that there is no substitute to establishing a central administration. Emir Abdullah


 arrives in Ma'an


 on 21 November, coming from the Hijaz


, ostensibly to support exiled Syrian officers in their struggle against the French.

title: 5th Zionist Congress Is Held in Basel
description:
The 5th Zionist Congress establishes the  Keren Kayemeth Leisrael (Jewish National Fund) 

 for the purpose of raising funds for land purchase in Palestine, opens a branch of the Jewish Colonial Trust

 in Jaffa


, and approves of a program focusing on developing Hebrew culture.

title: 9th Zionist Congress Is Held in Hamburg
description: Zionist representatives from Palestine participate in the congress for the first time. Differences between "practical" Zionists and "political" Zionists on how to implement the Zionist agenda are not resolved. The congress decides to create a cooperative settlement society in Palestine.

title: Conquest of Damascus; Faisal Enters Liberated City
description:
Arab troops supported by British forces continue their push north of Transjordan


 from Amman


 to Mafraq


 along the Hijaz Railway

, then liberate Dar'a


 on 27 September and reach the southern outskirts of Damascus


 on 30 September. Other British forces follow another axis, passing by Jisr Banat Ya'qub


, then Quneitra


 before heading to Damascus. Fearing encirclement, Ottoman forces withdraw further north and leave the city on 30 September. Prince Faisal


 enters Damascus on 3 October, leading a parade of Arab troops. He is acclaimed by Damascenes. Aleppo


 will be liberated on 25 October.

title: Conquest of Damascus; Faisal Enters Liberated City
description:
Arab troops supported by British forces continue their push north of Transjordan


 from Amman


 to Mafraq


 along the Hijaz Railway

, then liberate Dar'a


 on 27 September and reach the southern outskirts of Damascus


 on 30 September. Other British forces follow another axis, passing by Jisr Banat Ya'qub


, then Quneitra


 before heading to Damascus. Fearing encirclement, Ottoman forces withdraw further north and leave the city on 30 September. Prince Faisal


 enters Damascus on 3 October, leading a parade of Arab troops. He is acclaimed by Damascenes. Aleppo


 will be liberated on 25 October.

title: Conquest of Damascus; Faisal Enters Liberated City
description:
Arab troops supported by British forces continue their push north of Transjordan


 from Amman


 to Mafraq


 along the Hijaz Railway

, then liberate Dar'a


 on 27 September and reach the southern outskirts of Damascus


 on 30 September. Other British forces follow another axis, passing by Jisr Banat Ya'qub


, then Quneitra


 before heading to Damascus. Fearing encirclement, Ottoman forces withdraw further north and leave the city on 30 September. Prince Faisal


 enters Damascus on 3 October, leading a parade of Arab troops. He is acclaimed by Damascenes. Aleppo


 will be liberated on 25 October.

title: Conquest of Damascus; Faisal Enters Liberated City
description:
Arab troops supported by British forces continue their push north of Transjordan


 from Amman


 to Mafraq


 along the Hijaz Railway

, then liberate Dar'a


 on 27 September and reach the southern outskirts of Damascus


 on 30 September. Other British forces follow another axis, passing by Jisr Banat Ya'qub


, then Quneitra


 before heading to Damascus. Fearing encirclement, Ottoman forces withdraw further north and leave the city on 30 September. Prince Faisal


 enters Damascus on 3 October, leading a parade of Arab troops. He is acclaimed by Damascenes. Aleppo


 will be liberated on 25 October.

title: A General Palestinian Congress Meets in Damascus
description: Representatives from Palestine, members of the General Syrian Congress present in Damascus, hold a separate meeting (they call the General Palestinian Congress) in which they affirm their refusal to consider "Southern Syria (Palestine) as not part of Syria."

title: 1st Palestinian National Congress Is Held in Jerusalem
description:
Initiated by the Muslim-Christian Societies, the first Palestinian National Congress


 meets promptly a few days after the opening of the Paris Peace Conference
. It adopts two documents that rely upon President Wilson
's principles, to be forwarded to members of the Paris conference: a report asserting Palestinian historical and political rights over Zionist claims and the Balfour Declaration

 (the report reflects the political culture of the Palestinian elite at that time); and a petition affirming Palestine (or Southern Syria) as being part of Syria
 and readiness to seek Great Britain

’s help for the development of the country “provided that this does not prejudice its independence and Arab unity.” The congress decides also to send a three-member delegation (Tawfiq Hamadeh


, Ahmad Ragheb Abu-al-Sa'ud al-Dajjani


, and Jubran Kuzma


) to the conference.

title: 7th Zionist Congress Is Held in Basel
description:
The 7th Zionist Congress is briefed by the investigatory commission about the Uganda

's "unsuitability" for Jewish mass settlement and adopts a resolution opposing any alternative to Palestine.

title: Recommendations of the King-Crane Commission
description: The commission recommends that the unity of Syria (comprising Lebanon and Palestine) be preserved and that Syria should be placed under one Mandatory power. On Palestine, the commissioners report that the Zionists with whom they met "looked forward to a practically complete dispossession of the present non-Jewish inhabitants of Palestine, by various forms of purchase" and that "no British officer, consulted by the Commissioners, believed that the Zionist program could be carried out except by force of arms." The report adds that decisions requiring the use of arms "are surely not gratuitously to be taken in the interests of a serious injustice." The commission recommends "a greatly reduced Zionist program" and consequently "that the Jewish immigration should be definitely limited and that the project for making Palestine distinctly a Jewish commonwealth should be given up." The commission reiterates that there is no reason why Palestine could not be included in a united Syrian state. Though the findings and recommendations of the commission are significant, they are far from expressing a consensus within the US administration. Of note: the report is made public only in 1922.

title: First Stage of British Palestine Campaign: Gaza Does not Fall
description:
The British Palestine campaign against the Ottomans starts with the attempt to conquer Gaza
. The British had recovered the whole of the Sinai Peninsula


 from the Ottomans (who had occupied it since January 1915) with the capture of Rafah


 on 9 January. To conquer Jerusalem


, a much coveted prize, the British choose to advance from Rafah through Gaza. On 28 February, they occupy Khan Yunis


 without a fight, the Ottomans having decided to defend Gaza. A first attempt on 25–26 March to occupy Gaza fails, as does a second attempt on 17–19 April.

title: Treaty of Versailles; Establishment of the League of Nations
description:
Five months after the opening of the Paris Peace Conference
, the Allied Powers

 sign with Germany

 the Treaty of Versailles

 (28 June). Part I of the treaty consists of the covenant of an intergovernmental organization, the League of Nations

, to be established with the purpose of promoting international cooperation and achieving international peace and security. The League of Nations Covenant

 officially takes effect on 10 January 1920, and the first session of the League's Assembly will be held on 15 November, with 41 states attending.

title: Formation of the Covenant Society in Istanbul
description:
With the extinction of the Qahtani Society


, some of its military members, including Ali al-Nashashibi


 (a military doctor from Jerusalem


), found the secret Covenant Society


 in Istanbul

; it does not differ from the Qahtani Society in terms of its goals. However, the founders decide to limit membership to the military component, as they feel the civilians in the Qahtani Society were the reason for its failure and the disclosure of its secret existence. Iraqi officers, who set up branches in both Baghdad


 and Mosul


, make up the majority of the covenant's membership. The covenant may be considered the military counterpart to the civilian Young Arab Society


. Members of both secret organizations will play a central role in the Arab Revolt
 and in supporting Faisal
’s rule in Damascus


.

title: 4th Palestinian National Congress Is Held in Jerusalem
description:
The congress decides to send a Palestinian delegation to London

 to explain the Palestinian case against Balfour Declaration

: "the Palestine people will never admit the right of any outside organization to dispossess them of their country." The delegation will arrive in London on 2 August and remain almost one year (leaving 31 July 1922).

 to explain the Palestinian case against Balfour Declaration

: "the Palestine people will never admit the right of any outside organization to dispossess them of their country." The delegation will arrive in London on 2 August and remain almost one year (leaving 31 July 1922).

title: Ottoman Consolidated Regulations on Jewish Residence and Land Purchase in Palestine
description:
The Ottoman Council of Ministers in Istanbul

 issues consolidated regulations relative to Jewish residence and land purchase in Palestine to enter into force on 28 January 1901. Foreign Jews who are "long resident" in Palestine (i.e. implicitly including illegal Jewish residents) and those "whose residence is not prohibited" are to enjoy the same rights as Ottoman subjects, and are allowed to buy miri land (land whose bare ownership belongs to the state and usufruct to people who invest it) and build on it in accordance with the Land Code. Directives to ensure that Jewish pilgrims do not overstay in Palestine and do not purchase land are also issued. A "Special Commission for the Prevention of Jewish Immigrants from Settling in Palestine" is set up in Jerusalem


. By regularizing past residence and land purchase violations, the Ottoman government hopes that the restrictions it is reaffirming will be finally implemented. However, the restrictions will prove to be no more effective than the earlier ones issued since 1881.

title: Creation of Underground Bar Giora Group
description:
Jews who had come to Palestine during the second immigration wave meet at the home of Yitzhak Ben-Zvi

 (who will be elected the second president of the State of Israel in 1952) in Jaffa


 and establish an underground paramilitary group under the name of "Bar Giora Group

" (Bar Giora is believed to have participated in the revolt against the Romans in the first century). They adopt the motto: "In fire and blood did Judea

 fall; in blood and fire Judea shall rise." They call for establishing outposts to guard Jewish colonies and retaliating with force against what they would consider an Arab infringement.

title: Official Onset of British Mandate for Palestine
description:
As France

 and Italy

 notify the Council of the League of Nations

 that they have reached a final agreement in regard to the mandate for Syria


, the council notes that the mandates for Palestine and Syria would now enter into force automatically and at the same time.

title: Nabi Musa Festival: Palestinian Mobilization and Palestinian-Zionist Clashes
description:
The Muslim community in Palestine celebrate the Nabi Musa


 festival, as it has done every year since at least the early Ottoman period. Festivities start with a procession in Jerusalem on the Friday preceding the Christian Orthodox Good Friday (which, in 1920, fall respectively on 2 and 9 April) and last for 7 days, during which worshippers come from different towns (such as Hebron and Jaffa) to join the Jerusalemites heading to Nabi Musa shrines south of Jericho. The procession on 2 April passes off without incident and meets peacefully with another Christian procession to commemorate Catholic Good Friday, which happens to fall this year on this day. On 4 April, Zionist youth provoke Palestinian participants, triggering violent clashes that will end 3 days later and will cause the death of 5 Jews and 4 Palestinians and the injury of more than 200 Jews and 21 Palestinians. The violence of the confrontation occurs against the backdrop of Palestinians mobilized against the threatening implementation of the Balfour Declaration and impacted by the proclamation (3 March) of Syria’s independence under Faisal. Between 60,000 and 70,000 participate in the festival compared to an average of 15,000 at the beginning of the 20th century. On 6 April, Jerusalem notables accuse the Zionist Commission of being “a government within a government” and of training and arming the Jews in Palestine.

title: The General Syrian Congress and the King-Crane Commission
description:
Attended by delegates from all over Bilad al-Sham


, including Palestine, the General Syrian Congress


 conveys to the King-Crane Commission

 a message that recalls the "noble principles" laid down by President Woodrow Wilson

 and asserts the Congress position on the future of Syria


: independence and unity of Syria (including Lebanon


 and Palestine) based on broad decentralization principles; rejection of Article 22 of the League of Nations Covenant

 (that places Syria under a Mandatory regime); if, nevertheless, Article 22 is to be applied, seeking a 20-year technical and economic assistance by the United States

 that does not prejudice complete independence; accepting Great Britain

 as a substitute for the United States; rejection of any French role in any part of Syria; rejection of Jewish immigration and of the Zionist demand to create a "Jewish Commonwealth" in Palestine; ensuring the common rights and common obligations of "our Jewish compatriots."

title: The Palestinian Delegation Conducts Sterile Negotiations in London
description:
The Palestinian delegation appointed by the 4th National Congress and presided over by Musa Kazim al-Husseini


 conducts arduous negotiations with British authorities during 12 months in London. It seeks to develop relations with members of the two houses of Parliament and the press. It presents the Palestinian case, exposes how the Balfour Declaration contradicts the British pledges contained in the Hussein–McMahon correspondence, underlines the "injustice" of the present British policy, and complains about the influence exerted by the local Zionist leadership over the British administration in Palestine. But it fails to get any concession from the British government.

title: Churchill and Abdullah Reach Preliminary Understanding over Transjordan
description:
Emir Abdullah


 leaves Ma'an


 for Amman


 on 2 March. Newly appointed Secretary of State for the Colonies Winston Churchill

 initiates in Cairo


 on 12–22 March a special conference attended by British experts on the Middle East


. Among other matters, the conference results in two outcomes: to agree to Faisal
 (who had left Syria


 in July 1920 with the French conquest of Damascus


) becoming king of Iraq


 and to consider the acceptance of Abdullah as emir of Transjordan


 and the emergence of a central administration. Churchill and Abdullah appear to reach an understanding on the latter matter in meetings they hold in Jerusalem


 on 28–30 March. The meetings include other matters also: Abdullah’s assurances related to preventing Syrian refugees agitation against the French in Syria and to abstaining from undermining British control of Palestine, and Churchill’s assurances that, in the Palestine Mandate under discussion, its pro-Zionist clauses will not apply east of the Jordan River


. Finally, Churchill conditions his support for Prince Abdullah on the latter's success in controlling the situation in Transjordan within six months.

title: France and the Ottoman Empire Sign the Mytilene Agreements
description:
The Mytilene Agreements (an exchange of diplomatic letters on 2, 4, 6, 9 and 10 November) are reached by France

 and the Ottoman Empire

, confirming the privileges granted to Catholic French institutions in the Empire and the role of France in protecting them. In Palestine (and particularly in Jerusalem


), this applies to about 40 French religious communities and to institutions that depend on them (schools, hospices, orphanages). These communities are thus legally recognized and are exempt from property and direct municipal taxes and from customs. On 18 December 1913, the two sides will sign the "Constantinople Agreement" strenghtening the French privileges. In accordance with these agreements and the principle of state succession, the British Mandate will acknowledge the legal status of  French institutions in Palestine in September 1922; so too will Israel in January 1949 for the part of Palestine under its control. The Palestinian Authority will do so in December 1997.

title: Balfour Declaration Is Made
description:
British Foreign Secretary Lord Arthur James Balfour

 sends a letter (known as the Balfour Declaration

) to Baron Lionel Walter de Rothschild

 pledging British support for the establishment of a Jewish National Home in Palestine.

title: Establishment of the Arab-Ottoman Brotherhood Society in Istanbul
description:
Shukri al-Husseini


 and Jamil al-Husseini


 from Jerusalem


 participate in a large meeting of Arabs living in Istanbul

, attended by members of the Committee of Union and Progress

 (CUP), less than six weeks after the latter’s seizure of power. The meeting announces the formation of the Arab-Ottoman Brotherhood Society


. The society supports the restoration of the Ottoman Constitution of 1876 and the equality of all components of the Ottoman Empire

 within a single state, and it aims to ensure that Arabs have constitutional equality in getting jobs and positions, to raise the status of Arabs and the Arabic language, and to have schools established and books and newspapers published. The society declares that it welcomes Arabs of all creeds to join it, and it decides to establish branches throughout the Arab provinces. At the end of April 1909, shortly after retaking control of Istanbul following a 10-day counterrevolution (13-24 April), the CUP government closes the society, under the pretext of its support for the counterrevolution. The move to shut down the Arab-Ottoman Brotherhood Society and other non-Turkish associations indicates the Young Turks

 movement's fear of the rising calls for decentralized governance in Arab and other non-Turkish provinces.

title: 11th Zionist Congress Meets in Vienna
description:
The congress defines immigration to Palestine as a Zionist obligation, a duty of each Zionist. It calls for establishing a Hebrew University

 in Jerusalem


. (The university will be effectively created in 1925 during the British Mandate.)

title: Formation of the Moderate Liberal Party and the Entente Libérale Party in Istanbul
description:
Members of the Ottoman Parliament

, including Sa'id al-Husseini


 and Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


, establish in Istanbul

 the Moderate Liberal Party


; it is an Arab grouping but includes members representing other components of the Ottoman state, since the Law of Associations, which had been passed a few weeks earlier, prohibits the formation of political associations on an ethnic or national basis. Accordingly, the party's statute emphasizes the unity of the state and rejects decentralism, federalism, and discrimination on the basis of race or community. However, the party's emphasis on the need for the Ottoman state to undertake comprehensive reforms in all fields indicates implicitly a rejection of the "Turkification" policy pursued by the Committee of Union and Progress

. Regarding education, for example, the party calls for protecting the language and literature of each group of the Ottoman population from extinction. On 8 November 1911, party members and other politicians form a new opposition party, the Entente Libérale Party


, whose members are also predominantly Arab.

title: The Ottomans Sign the Armistice of Mudros; Istanbul Is Occupied
description:
Having lost all of their Arab provinces to the British army (and secondarily to the French) and threatened on their western front, the Ottomans sign with the British, representing Allied Powers

, the Armistice of Mudros

 on 30 October 1918. On 12 November, French troops enter Istanbul

, followed by British troops the next day. The Ottoman sultanate is left in place by the Allied Powers.

title: The Ottomans Sign the Armistice of Mudros; Istanbul Is Occupied
description:

, the Armistice of Mudros

 on 30 October 1918. On 12 November, French troops enter Istanbul

, followed by British troops the next day. The Ottoman sultanate is left in place by the Allied Powers.
