title: Second Stage of British Palestine Campaign: From Bir al-Sabi' and Gaza to Jerusalem
description:
General Edmund Allenby

 launches the Third Gaza Battle

 (after the failure of the two previous ones in March and April). The military campaign starts with the capture of Bir al-Sabi'


 on 31 October, immediately followed by the fight for Gaza
 and the Gaza-Bir al-Sabi' defensive line held by the Ottoman forces (1–7 November). The British occupy the village of al-Maghar


 (13–14 November), west of the railway station where the line from Jerusalem


 joins the north–south line. On 15–16 November, they occupy Ramla


, Lydda


, Jaffa


, and al-Latrun


. To conquer Jerusalem, British forces try to force the Ottomans to leave the city by cutting roads leading to it and attempt to advance along two main axes: from al-Latrun to the north of Jerusalem (passing by Imwas


, Bayt 'Ur al-Fawqa


, and Nabi Samu'il


); from Bir al-Sabi' to the south of the city (through Hebron


 and Bethlehem


). Ottoman counterattacks delay British advances on several fronts from mid-November to the first week of December when the Ottomans decide to evacuate the city. They leave on 8-9 December after the Ottoman Mutasarrif signs the surrender letter of the city and transmits it to the mayor of Jerusalem, Hussein Salim al-Husseini


, for delivery to the British.

title: Palestinians Clash with Settlers of Sejera Colony
description:
Clashes initiated by Palestinians from al-Shajara


 and Kafr Kanna


 villages against the neighboring colony of Sejera

 (between Nazareth


 and Tiberias


) lead to the killing of two Palestinians and two Jews and the injury of several people on both sides over the course of a few days. Palestinians are probably emboldened by the atmosphere of greater freedom created by the Young Turks

 Revolution to challenge the compromises they were forced to make with the Jewish colonies on land ownership and use in the previous years; the settlers are encouraged by members of the Bar Giora Group

 who joined the colony in 1907 and took over the guard of the settlement, which previously had been guarded by hired Kafr Kanna villagers.

title: Theodor Herzl Dies; Replaced by David Wolffsohn
description:
David Wolffsohn

, a close associate of Theodor Herzl

 and director of the Jewish Colonial Trust

, takes over the leadership of the Zionist movement.

title: White Paper (Churchill) of 1922 Clarifies the Terms of the Balfour Declaration
description:
At a time when the Palestinian delegation in London

 makes its case against the Balfour Declaration

, Winston Churchill

, then-Secretary of State for the Colonies, publishes a White Paper
 detailing the British understanding of the Declaration. It states that the Declaration does not contemplate that Palestine "as a whole" should be converted into a Jewish National Home, but that such a Home should be founded "in Palestine." However, it affirms that Jews are in Palestine "as of right and not on the sufferance" and explains that the British commitment to the Jewish national home entails that the Jewish community in Palestine should be able to increase its numbers by immigration. In order to respond to the Palestinian delegation's assertion that British/ McMahon
 pledges concerning Arab independence include Palestine, the White Paper, in its defense of the Balfour Declaration, claims (falsely) that the exclusions indicated by McMahon to Sharif Hussein
 concerned "the Vilayet of Beirut
 and the independent Sanjaq of Jerusalem


" and that "the whole of Palestine west of the Jordan
 was thus excluded from Sir. Henry McMahon's pledge."

title: 13th Zionist Congress Is Held in Carlsbad (Karlovy Vary)
description:
The Zionist Congress
 discusses and rejects the participation of non-Zionist Jews in a Jewish Agency to be established as provided for in Article 4 of the Mandate. The latter had requested the Zionist Organization

 "to secure the co-operation of all Jews who are willing to assist in the establishment of the Jewish national home."

title: Establishment of the Anglo-Palestine Company
description:
The Anglo-Palestine Company

 (APC, a subsidiary of the Jewish Colonial Trust

 in London

) is the first Zionist organization to seek establishment in Palestine (July). Ottoman authorities in Jerusalem


 and Istanbul

 are aware that the bank is connected with the Zionist movement and has the aim of carrying out its program. The Porte tries to obstruct the licensing of APC operations in Palestine. However, the British embassy in Istanbul pressures the Porte to permit (in November)  APC "to conduct its affairs without hindrance so long as it confined its operations to commercial matters." The first branch of APC opens in Jaffa


.

title: The [Palestine] Arab Executive Committee Orders the Return of its Delegation from London
description:
Many Palestinian associations send cables to the Palestine Arab Delegation calling it to break off the negotiations it conducts in London and to return to Palestine. On 8 July, the [Palestine] Arab Executive Committee


 emanating from the 4th National Congress adopts a resolution requesting the delegation "to return at once" after announcing to the British Government and the League of Nations that "Palestine Arabs reject Mandate system all together in view of Churchill's statement that Balfour Declaration is an indivisible part of Mandate." The delegation returns to Palestine on 31 July after protesting to the League of Nations for its endorsement of the Mandate on 24 July.

title: The [Palestine] Arab Executive Committee Orders the Return of its Delegation from London
description:

title: The General Syrian National Congress Proclaims the Independence of the Arab Syrian Kingdom
description:
The General Syrian Congress proclaims the independence of the Arab Syrian Kingdom


 (that includes the territories of Syria


, Lebanon


, Palestine and Transjordan


) with Prince Faisal


 as king.

title: British-French Demarcation of Line Between Palestine (Including Transjordan) and Syria (Including Lebanon)
description:
An exchange of notes constituting an agreement between Britain
 and France

 as Mandatory powers over Palestine and Syria


, respectively, traces on the spot the boundary line between the two territories from the Mediterranean
 to al-Himma


 (i.e. separating Lebanon


 and Syria to the north and Palestine and Transjordan


 to the south), and includes three detailed maps on a scale of 1/50000. Known as the Paulet–Newcombe Agreement

, it implements the Franco-British Convention of 23 December 1920

 .

title: Palestinian Peasants in Tiberias Score a Rare Success Against Zionist Land Acquisition
description:
In contravention to its own directives, the Ottoman Council of Ministers gives the green light to the projected sale of land to Narcisse Leven

, a French Jew and president of the Jewish Colonization Association

 (JCA), with the justification that Leven is entitled as a foreigner to acquire land, provided he gives assurances that he would not install foreign Jews on it. Leven acquires 31,500 dunams near Tiberias


 from the Beirut


 family of the Sursocks. Palestinian peasants who are tenants of the land (from Lubya


 and Abbadiyya


 villages) harass JCA surveyors on several occasions. Their protest against the sale is supported by Amin Arslan


, the qa’im maqam (subdistrict commissioner) of Tiberias. The disquiet brought about by the sale finally leads to its abrogation by Istanbul

. (Similar attempts by Leven to purchase land in the Sanjaq of Jerusalem


 are also rejected by Istanbul in 1901.) However, settlements in the Tiberias area continue to expand between 1901 and 1904, resulting in further clashes with Palestinian peasants.

title: Transfer of Land Amendment Ordinance No. 2
description: Faced with widespread discontent from both Arab and Zionist organizations on the 1920 Land Transfer Ordinance, the British decide to remove all restrictions on the disposition of land, except for the provision meant to ensure that the “tenant in occupation” retains enough land for himself and his family. However, in the near decade that follows illegal methods are systematically and successfully implemented by both sellers and buyers to circumvent the tenant’s protection.

title: The Fourteen Points of US President Woodrow Wilson
description:
US
 President Woodrow Wilson

 makes a major speech before the Congress
 recalling the moral basis of US involvement in World War I

 and outlining the principles, both general and territorial, for a stable and enduring world peace. The speech, which occurs nine weeks after the Balfour Declaration

 (which Wilson had secretly endorsed in mid-October 1917 before it was announced on 2 November), is due in part to the Bolsheviks’ disclosure (on 23 November 1917) of the secret Sykes-Picot Agreement

. Wilson summarizes his peace principles in 14 points, condemns secret understandings between states, and advocates peoples’ right to self-determination (though he does not use this expression literally in his speech). Concerning the Ottoman Empire

, he states: “the other nationalities which are now under Turkish rule should be assured an undoubted security of life and an absolutely unmolested opportunity of autonomous development.” Analysts and historians will note the incompatibility between Wilson’s points and his endorsement of the terms of the Balfour Declaration.

title: The Russian Revolution; Sykes-Picot Agreement Is Published
description:
Fueled by discontent with the Tsarist regime and the effects of World War I

, the Russian Revolution of 1917
 brings the Bolsheviks, led by Vladimir Lenin

, to power. The Bolsheviks seize control on 7 November (corresponding to 25 October, Julian calendar) establishing the world's first communist state. On 23 November, the Bolsheviks make public and denounce the Sykes-Picot Agreement

. This will make it easier for Great Britain

 to retract from its acceptance of an international status for Palestine as provided for in the agreement and according to which Russia

 was to be consulted.

title: Establishment of Muslim-Christian Societies: Towards National Representation in Palestine
description:
Muslim-Christian associations are established in Palestinian towns, starting with Jaffa on 8 May. Within a short period, 27 are created. At the end of January 1919, their representatives hold a national meeting in Jerusalem


 that constitutes the First Palestinian National Congress


. Seven congresses are held between 1919 and 1928.  Starting with the 3rd, each congress will elect an executive committee to conduct business between sessions.

title: Amin al-Husseini Elected Mufti of Jerusalem
description:
Muhammad Amin al-Husseini


 is elected mufti of Jerusalem


 after the death of his elder brother Kamel al-Husseini


, who had held this position. He will be elected head of the Supreme Moslem Council
 on 9 January 1922.

title: Amin al-Husseini Elected Mufti of Jerusalem
description:
Muhammad Amin al-Husseini


 is elected mufti of Jerusalem


 after the death of his elder brother Kamel al-Husseini


, who had held this position. He will be elected head of the Supreme Moslem Council
 on 9 January 1922.

title: Amin al-Husseini Elected Mufti of Jerusalem
description:
Muhammad Amin al-Husseini


 is elected mufti of Jerusalem


 after the death of his elder brother Kamel al-Husseini


, who had held this position. He will be elected head of the Supreme Moslem Council
 on 9 January 1922.

title: Amin al-Husseini Elected Mufti of Jerusalem
description:
Muhammad Amin al-Husseini


 is elected mufti of Jerusalem


 after the death of his elder brother Kamel al-Husseini


, who had held this position. He will be elected head of the Supreme Moslem Council
 on 9 January 1922.

title: Founding of the Arab National Party in Jerusalem
description:
Several Palestinian figures (including As'ad al-Shuqairi


, Aref Dajjani


, Fakhri al-Nashashibi


, Suleiman al-Taji al-Faruqi


, Omar al-Saleh al-Barghouti


, and Boulos Shehadeh


) announce the establishment of the Arab National Party


 in Jerusalem


. The goals of the party are similar to those of the national movement, such as rejection of the Balfour Declaration

 and establishment of an elected legislative assembly (and in fact, the party was created with the encouragement of Mandate authorities in order to split the Palestinian national movement led by Haj Amin al-Husseini
). The party does not succeed in gaining popular support, and party branches established in major cities are short-lived.

title: 10th Zionist Congress Is Held in Basel
description:
The friction between practical and political Zionists comes to an end through the adoption of the "synthetic" approach proposed by Chaim Weizmann

. The congress adopts the position that the Jewish problem could be solved only by Jewish emigration to Palestine.

title: The British Prepare for the Occupation of Palestine
description:
On 9 January, British forces retake the town of Rafah


 and reach the border which, according to the 1906 British-Ottoman agreement

, constitutes the demarcation line between the Ottoman territory and Egypt


. Having thus recovered the whole of the Sinai Peninsula


 (which the Ottoman army had conquered in January 1915), British forces prepare for their next step: capturing Palestine, at the center of which is Jerusalem


, a much-coveted prize, and Syria
. They will achieve this objective in stages between February 1917 and October 1918 with the conquest of Damascus


. Arab troops under Prince Faisal


’s leadership will play a not-insignificant role in British success.

title: The Palestine Communist Party Is Officially Announced
description: The announcement comes as the party (Jewish) leaders declare their acceptance of the conditions set by the Communist International (Comintern): to change its name from Socialist Workers Party (a name it had adopted in October 1919) to Communist Party; to conduct a policy of "Arabization"; and to sever its ties with Zionist socialists.

title: Arrival in Palestine of the Zionist Commission
description:
The Zionist Commission

, led by Chaim Weizmann

, is officially defined as the "advisory body to the British authorities in Palestine in all matters relating to Jews, or which may affect the establishment of a National Home for the Jewish People."

title: Palestinian-Zionist Tension at al-Shajara - Sejera in the Tiberias Region
description:
Tension between Palestinian farmers of al-Shajara


 (and also Lubya


) and Zionist settlers of Sejera colony in the Tiberias


 region breaks out over delimitation of land ownership. A Jewish settler is killed.

title: Zionist Evasion of Ottoman Regulations
description:
The Ottoman governor of Jerusalem


 issues a report that describes how Zionist immigration and land acquisition evade the regulations in force.

title: Zionist Evasion of Ottoman Regulations
description:
The Ottoman governor of Jerusalem


 issues a report that describes how Zionist immigration and land acquisition evade the regulations in force.

title: Zionist Evasion of Ottoman Regulations
description:
The Ottoman governor of Jerusalem


 issues a report that describes how Zionist immigration and land acquisition evade the regulations in force.

title: Zionist Evasion of Ottoman Regulations
description:
The Ottoman governor of Jerusalem


 issues a report that describes how Zionist immigration and land acquisition evade the regulations in force.

title: The Zionist Organization Opens an Office in Jaffa
description:
Implementing a decision adopted by the 8th Zionist Congress
 (held in July 1907), the Zionist Organization

 opens an office in Jaffa


. The Palestine office will devote all its energies to acquiring land and establishing Jewish colonies, and it will centralize the different colonization initiatives, whether they come from philanthropic organizations or from immigrant associations.

title: Establishment of Palestinian Newspaper al-Karmel in Haifa
Formation of the Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization in Cairo
description:
Some Arab nationalists, who had taken refuge in Egypt


 to escape Ottoman repression, establish the Ottoman Party for Administrative Decentralization


 in Cairo


. The party includes Salim Abd al-Hadi


 and Hassan Hammad


 from Nablus


, Hafiz al-Sa'id


 from Jaffa


, Ali al-Nashashibi


 from Jerusalem


, Sa'id al-Karmi


 from Tulkarm


, and Salim al-Ahmad


 from Jenin


. It calls for according administrative decentralization to the Arab provinces, recognizing Arabic as an official language, employing Arabs in government departments according to their proportion to the population of the Ottoman Empire

, and having military service done locally in the provinces in times of peace. The party establishes branches in every city in the Levant
 and Iraq


 with approximately 10,000 members, and within about a year, it becomes the most organized and credible expression of Arab aspirations. The party plays a key role in organizing the First Arab Congress


 in Paris

 in June 1913. In 1916, the Ottoman authorities execute some of its members.

title: Establishment of the Histadrut
description:
HaHistadrut HaKlalit shel HaOvdim B'Eretz Yisrael (the General Organization of Workers in Eretz Yisrael) is established in Haifa


 by Zionist leaders.

title: Palestinians Boycott Elections
description:
Elections are held to replace the temporary Advisory Council
, constituted in October 1920, with a Legislative Council as provided for in the Palestine Order in Council. In accordance with the decisions of the 5th Palestinian National Congress


, the Palestinians decide to boycott the elections.

title: Publication of The Awakening of the Arab Nation in Asiatic Turkey by Najib Azoury
description:
Najib Azoury, a former Ottoman civil servant in the sanjaq of Jerusalem, publishes Le réveil de la nation arabe dans l'Asie turque. He calls for the separation of Arab provinces from the Ottoman Empire

 and warns of the emergence of two important phenomena: "the awakening of the Arab nation and the latent efforts of the Jews to reconstitute on a very large scale the ancient kingdom of Israel. Both these movements are destined to fight each other continuously until one of them wins. The fate of the entire world will depend on the final result of this struggle between these two peoples representing two contrary principles."

title: Establishment of Filastin Newspaper in Jaffa
description:
The newspaper Filastin
 is established in Jaffa


 by Isa al-Isa


. It addresses its readers as Palestinians.

title: European Powers Renew Pressure on the Ottomans to Ease Zionist Land Acquisition in Palestine
description: Description not found

title: Establishment of the Literary Club in Istanbul
description:
In the summer of 1909, Jamil al-Husseini


 and Aref al-Aref


 (Jerusalem


), Asim Bseiso


 (Gaza


), Nasib al-Bitar


, and Rushdi Saleh Malhas


 (Nablus


) co-found the Literary Club


, which includes Arab deputies to the Ottoman Parliament

 and intellectuals and students studying in Istanbul

. The formation of the association comes a few months after the dissolution of the Arab-Ottoman Brotherhood Society


. The founders are keen to adopt a non-political name for their new organization and declare that their goal is to "strengthen the bonds of brotherhood between Arabs of different races, religions, ethnicities, and sects." Thousands of intellectuals and students will join the association's many branches in Syria
 and Iraq


, some of them after completing their studies in Istanbul. Although the association will avoid getting involved in politics, it will contribute to popularizing the idea of pan-Arabism among intellectual circles in Arab regions, and some of its leaders will play a nationalist political role. In March 1915, the Ottoman authorities will ban the Literary Club, arresting and executing some of its members, including its president, Abd al-Karim Khalil


 (who lives in Burj al-Barajneh


, near Beirut


), and his deputy, Rafiq Salloum


 (Homs


).

title: International Zionist Conference Meets in London
description:
Though not a formal Zionist Congress, the International Zionist Conference establishes the Keren Hayesod (Foundation Fund)

 as a mechanism to collect funds among world Jewish communities.

title: Palestinian Members of the Ottoman Parliament Express Opposition to Zionist Objectives
description:
Hafiz al-Sa'id


, deputy from Jaffa


, submits a question to the Presidium of the Ottoman Chamber of Deputies

, asking whether Zionism

 was compatible with the interests of the empire and demanding that the port of Jaffa be closed to Jewish immigrants. In an interview to Ha-Zvi

, a Jerusalemite Hebrew newspaper published on 1 November, Sa'id al-Husseini


, deputy from Jerusalem


, declares that he favors the immigration of Jews to the empire at large but opposes their mass entry into Palestine. Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


, the other deputy from Jerusalem, expresses on the following day to the same newspaper his opposition to founding colonies in Palestine and, given the financial capacity of the Ashkenazim, his fear of having them "buy many tracts of land and displace the Arab farmers from their land and their fathers' inheritance."

title: Arab Ottoman Parliamentarians Address Minister of Interior
description: Deputies from Arab provinces request assurances from the Ottoman minister of the interior regarding Zionist land acquisition in Palestine.

title: Arab Ottoman Parliamentarians Address Minister of Interior
description: Deputies from Arab provinces request assurances from the Ottoman minister of the interior regarding Zionist land acquisition in Palestine.

title: Arab Ottoman Parliamentarians Address Minister of Interior
description: Deputies from Arab provinces request assurances from the Ottoman minister of the interior regarding Zionist land acquisition in Palestine.

title: Arab Ottoman Parliamentarians Address Minister of Interior
description: Deputies from Arab provinces request assurances from the Ottoman minister of the interior regarding Zionist land acquisition in Palestine.

title: Founding of the Haganah, the Jewish Paramilitary Organization
description:
The Zionist leadership decides to establish a centralized paramilitary organization, the  Haganah 

 (defense) to provide defense to the Jewish communities in Palestine. It is envisioned as a national popular organization, differing from previous Jewish defense groups such as Hashomer

 (established in April 1909), which operated as a small independent guard force. Haganah is placed first under the auspices of the Histadrut

. It will be put in the early 1930s under the authority of the  World Zionist Organization 

 and will evolve into a more organized combat force over the years to eventually play a major role in the 1948 War
.

title: Zionist Attempt to Buy 1.5 Million Dunams in the Jordan Valley
description:
As the new Ottoman regime looks for ways to rehabilitate the empire's finances, the Jewish Colonization Association

 (JCA) makes (March) a bid for buying some half a million dunams of jiftlik land (land that was held under the name of Sultan Abd al-Hamid II


) in the region of Jericho


. Within the same month, Baron Edmond de Rothschild

 tenders an offer for about a million dunams at Baysan


. (The baron was a supporter of the JCA and had transferred to that entity, in 1899, the land on which he had established Jewish colonies in Palestine.) In July, Istanbul

 rejects these Zionist bids to get jiftlik in Palestine.

title: First Major Debate on Zionism in Ottoman Parliament
description:
After Palestinian delegates to the Ottoman Parliament

 (among others, Muhammad Ruhi al-Khalidi


 from Jerusalem


 and Hafiz al-Sa'id


 from Jaffa


) raise the issue of Zionism

, charging that the Zionist aim is to create a Jewish State in Palestine and calling for legislation against Zionist mass immigration to Palestine, the Ottoman parliament conducts its first major debate on Zionism.

title: Publication of Zionism by Najib Nassar
description:
Palestinian journalist Najib Nassar


 publishes the first book in Arabic on Zionism

, entitled Zionism: Its History, Objectives and Importance.

title: Advisory Council for Palestine Is Established
description:
The Advisory Council for Palestine

, set up by the new High Commissioner, Herbert Samuel

, includes 10 British officials, 4 Muslims, 3 Christians, and 2 Jews. Because the council is a temporary mechanism, the Palestinians do not boycott it in the beginning.

title: Prevention of Crime Ordinance is Issued
description: The Prevention of Crime Ordinance empowers district officials to impose a bond on or to arrest individuals “likely to commit a breach of the peace or to disturb the public tranquility.” In effect, it allows the Mandate government to bind over or arrest individuals who had committed no offense on the justification that, without such action, public order could not be guaranteed. The ordinance is published in the Palestine Gazette on 15 December 1920. In 1921, the ordinance will be amended to place such individuals under police supervision, denying them freedom of movement and forcing them to present themselves to police authorities whenever called upon to do so.

title: 1st British Census of Palestine
description: A census shows a total population of 757,182, with 78% Muslim, 11% Jewish, and 9.6% Christian.
